items.title: My #1 feature request for Claude Code should add is stop asking me every time for confirmation by de...
items.content:
My #1 feature request for Claude Code should add is stop asking me every time for confirmation by default, like "can I check this folder", yes brother you can do anything you want

Like maybe for writing ask me permission

Add some [ just go ] mode

Even with [ accept edits on ] it still asks me permission 1000 times per day

I just want you to run and keep going mostly

And no I don't feel like running it with --dangerously-skip-permissions

items.title: It's late 2024, a few days after I launched the first version of Claude Code (then called Claude CLI...
items.content:
It's late 2024, a few days after I launched the first version of Claude Code (then called Claude CLI) to team dogfooding. I walked into the office and saw my coworker Robert with a terminal up on his computer, Claude CLI running and a red/green diff view on screen.

I was surprised. This was back in the Sonnet 3.5 days, before the model was good at agentic coding. I had just given it a FileEdit tool the day before. Claude CLI was a prototype that I thought it wasn't useful for anything yet. But Robert was already starting to use it to write code & use git for him. I was still using the CLI as a note taker mostly, but I also started making it my go-to tool for using git as a result.

items.title:
‚úíÔ∏èHow I built an AI agent to automate my emails with LangSmith Agent Builder

LangSmith Agent Builde...
items.content:
‚úíÔ∏èHow I built an AI agent to automate my emails with LangSmith Agent Builder

LangSmith Agent Builder is a no-code agent builder. I built an email assistant to monitor and respond to emails, that I've been using for the last ~3 months. Here's what it looks like:

1/ Triggers: it is triggered by incoming emails. I don't have to do any work to kick it off - it just runs automatically

2/ Tools via MCP: connects to gmail (read emails, send email) and gcal (read calendar, read events, create event)

3/ Human in the loop: the "write" actions (sending email, creating calendar) require human approval to run. More on this later - but wanted to highlight that it's able to go completely wild!

4/ Subagent for calendar scheduling: LLMs suck at working with calendars! So i have a subagent specifically for finding my availability - its works a lot better

5/ Agent inbox to review: as mentioned, some actions require human approval. LangSmith Agent Builder ships with an agent inbox to review and approve the actions the agent wants to take

6/ message_user to ask questions: sometimes my agent doesn't know what it should do. It has a message_user tool, which it can use to ask me a question! This also shows up in agent inbox

7/ Remembers what I say: it updates it memory automatically based on my responses to it! This keeps me from having to repeat myself

Overall - I never look at my actual email anymore, just this!

I recorded a quick video about how I made it + how I use it: https://t.co/1A3KOWY5Bb

We made this into a template - so you can try it out easily here: https://t.co/1W0brFVBL2

And if you want to build your own agent - try out LangSmith Agent Builder here: https://t.co/eTKaLfVt9j

items.title: Over the next few months, this happened over and over. First our designer started using Claude Code ...
items.content:
Over the next few months, this happened over and over. First our designer started using Claude Code for prototypes and content fixes, then our finance person used it to build models and do financial forecasting, Sales used it to analyze data from Salesforce and bigquery, our user researcher used it to crunch survey results.

Fast forward to today, and people are using Claude Code to control their oven, recover wedding photos from a busted hard drive, analyze their DNA and medical records, haggle with customer support.

items.content:
It took me 28 minutes with Claude to:

1. Build a transactional web app with a React frontend, Supabase backend, and database, including user registration/email verification/sign-in.

2. Set up the CI/CD pipeline with GitHub and Cloudflare.

3. Connect the domain name.

So, 28 minutes from idea to implementation. Yes, the app is not doing anything useful yet, but it's up and running, accepting users, and ready to grow.

items.title:
Do filesystem tools üóÉÔ∏è kill vector search‚ùì

File search is all the rage right now. Give claude code ...
items.content:
Do filesystem tools üóÉÔ∏è kill vector search‚ùì

File search is all the rage right now. Give claude code access to the CLI and it turns into a generalized computer use agent.

This is a great blog post from @itsclelia that benchmarks file search vs. vector search. Up until ~100 files, the speed is comparable. From 1k files onwards, vector search is way faster to get an initial result.

File search does enable the agent to do dynamic reasoning to answer more complex questions (e.g. linking across different sections in the same doc). The real answer is probably blending both, ala what we did with semtools! https://t.co/xg1iqbghIr

Check out our blog: https://t.co/4QBpq8Ih4E

We used LlamaParse to parse all files into LLM-readable formats. 

fs-explorer repo: https://t.co/MBQSXV01Fb
LlamaCloud: https://t.co/QwzurFBE67
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu benchmarks file search vs vector search: similar speed up to ~100 files, vector search much faster at 1k+ files. Suggests blending both approaches.

items.title:
Over the last month or two, I've completely changed my software development workflow.

I'm now using...
items.content:
Over the last month or two, I've completely changed my software development workflow.

I'm now using:

‚Ä¢ Visual Studio Code + Copilot
‚Ä¢ Claude Code on the terminal (Opus 4.5)
‚Ä¢ Jules in the background (Gemini 3)

Before, most of my time went to writing code. I used to think "out loud" by writing my ideas over and over again in code.

That's not what I'm doing anymore.

Now, I'm spending most of the time writing and refining the specification of what I want to build.

For simple requests, I ask the model directly.

For more complex requests, I put together a complete specification with as many details as possible.

I also spend time reviewing the code the model writes for me. 80% of the time, it's just a quick glance to make sure things "feel" good. The other 20% of the time is looking very carefully at anything critical in the code.

I'm also making way more decisions than before. I feel I'm dealing with many more things, and I'm actually more involved in the final product than ever before.

From that point of view, AI is not making my job any easier. It's just changing it.

items.title:
Multi-Agent systems are all the rage, but how well are they actually working? ü§ñ

Our latest work wit...
items.content:
Multi-Agent systems are all the rage, but how well are they actually working? ü§ñ

Our latest work with IBM Research makes the case for MAST (Multi-Agent System Failure Taxonomy) as an emerging standard for agentic evaluation. Using MAST to map the ‚Äúfailure signatures‚Äù of systems like Gemini, GPT and Kimi-K2 reveals where and why these agents struggle in real enterprise workflows.

items.title: At some point all of this stopped being surprising. It became obvious that we should make it easier ...
items.content:
At some point all of this stopped being surprising. It became obvious that we should make it easier for people that want to use the Claude agent for things that are not coding. That's why we launched Claude Cowork today.

I felt sentimental about this launch because it reminded me of the early Claude Code days: the product is early, it doesn't work perfectly yet, but already people are finding it extremely useful for all sorts of things that are not obvious and also not coding. I can't wait to see how people use Cowork, and how the product evolves.

If you have any feedback as you use Cowork -- bugs, ideas, stuff we should build next -- tag me or @felixrieseberg 

https://t.co/YbdPGus3O6

items.title: I have no special knowledge of the Google-Apple AI deal, but if the phone becomes a vessel for worki...
items.content:
I have no special knowledge of the Google-Apple AI deal, but if the phone becomes a vessel for working with AI assistants, you probably want to own the assistant, not the phone.

Also a sign that, until things hit a wall, even well-resourced firms can't catch up with the frontier

items.title: A couple months later, many engineers & researchers at Anthropic were using Claude daily. There was ...
items.content:
A couple months later, many engineers & researchers at Anthropic were using Claude daily. There was one day I remember walking into the office and saw a Claude Code terminal up on our data scientist's computer monitor! I asked if he was trying out Claude Code, and was shocked to learn that he was using it to do his work, to write and run SQL queries for an analysis, and to make little ascii plots in the terminal and using matplotlib.

We built Claude Code for engineers, and here was a data scientist using it to do his work too. The next week, the entire row of data scientists had Claude Code up on their screens.
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny recalls data scientists adopting Claude Code for SQL queries and analysis, spreading organically within the team
items.reasoning: Important historical narrative of Claude Code adoption among non-engineers, high engagement
items.summary_html: Boris Cherny recalls data scientists adopting Claude Code for SQL queries and analysis, spreading organically within the team
items.content_html:
A couple months later, many engineers & researchers at Anthropic were using Claude daily. There was one day I remember walking into the office and saw a Claude Code terminal up on our data scientist's computer monitor! I asked if he was trying out Claude Code, and was shocked to learn that he was using it to do his work, to write and run SQL queries for an analysis, and to make little ascii plots in the terminal and using matplotlib.

We built Claude Code for engineers, and here was a data scientist using it to do his work too. The next week, the entire row of data scientists had Claude Code up on their screens.

items.title:
I'm willing to die on this hill:

The best voice models are those with the best accuracy with key en...
items.content:
I'm willing to die on this hill:

The best voice models are those with the best accuracy with key entities, not those that optimize for WER (Word Error Rate).

Most speech-to-text providers optimize for WER, but in production applications, WER is not that relevant.

Getting 95% of the words right is useless if you miss the customer's name, their phone number, or the street address they just spelled out letter by letter.

The team at Gladia ran a very cool benchmark:

‚Ä¢ 1,000+ call center conversations
‚Ä¢ Lots of background noise
‚Ä¢ Focus on extracting names, phone numbers, addresses, locations, etc.

The Gladia model outperformed every other state-of-the-art model by up to 17%!

This is exactly the data that matters to companies using these models. You get this wrong, and everything downstream breaks.

A few other things worth mentioning:

‚Ä¢ Latency on partials: < 150ms
‚Ä¢ 100+ languages supported
‚Ä¢ Dynamic language detection
‚Ä¢ Overall WER at 5.97%

Definitely worth checking for anyone using voice models:

https://t.co/QYY8WlMkKq

Thanks to the Gladia team for collaborating with me on this post.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago argues voice models should prioritize entity accuracy over WER, shares Gladia benchmark showing 17% improvement on names/numbers/addresses
items.reasoning: Original insight on speech-to-text evaluation metrics with concrete benchmark data, practical implications for production systems

items.title: The shelf life of the analysis layer, the taxonomies, market maps, "here's why this will/won't work"...
items.content: The shelf life of the analysis layer, the taxonomies, market maps, "here's why this will/won't work" takes is trending towards zero. They've always been somewhat provisional, but they used to have enough validity long enough to be useful. You could build a strategy on them. Now you can't. Models are changing too fast and are too capable. Principles over predictions. Principles are winning.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Analysis layer (taxonomies, market maps, predictions) is becoming worthless as models change too fast - principles over predictions is the winning strategy

items.title: @shadcn @peteskomoroch I had dinner about 13 years ago with Tom Gruber, who was running Siri at Appl...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Shares historical anecdote about Tom Gruber (Siri lead at Apple) knowing Google was winning in AI 13 years ago due to faster learning rates
items.reasoning: Unique insider perspective on Apple vs Google AI competition history, high engagement (42K views), provides interesting context on AI development trajectory
items.summary_html: Shares historical anecdote about Tom Gruber (Siri lead at Apple) knowing Google was winning in AI 13 years ago due to faster learning rates
items.content_html:
@shadcn @peteskomoroch I had dinner about 13 years ago with Tom Gruber, who was running Siri at Apple at the time. He told me he already knew that Google was beating Apple.

When I asked how he knew that, he said: "Well, we've instrumented all of Google and all of our stuff at Apple, and Google's AI is learning faster than ours is."

Unfortunately, they couldn't use that knowledge to fix the problem, and now Google is in charge of the AI.

items.title: Understanding embedded visual elements is a huge pain point for document OCR. With our latest releas...
items.content:
Understanding embedded visual elements is a huge pain point for document OCR. With our latest release, we offer one of the cheapest ways for you to get awesome visual parsing over charts, diagrams, etc. üí´

Screenshotting the page into a frontier VLM leads to a ton of failure modes; especially when you‚Äôre resolution constrained by the API provider. A lot of embedded elements like charts have a ton of visual detail that require specialized understanding.

We upgraded our agentic mode within LlamaParse and it‚Äôs fantastic at parsing visual subelements within a document, and stringing it together in to coherent markdown. It also comes with all the requisite metadata like bounding boxes, confidence scores, embedded images, and more.

Check out the parsed page below. The parser is able to accurately infer color mappings in the bar chart üìä
 and infer intermediate, nonmarked values in the line chart üìà. 

Sign up below!

https://t.co/QwzurFBE67

items.summary: Jerry Liu announces LlamaParse upgrade for visual document parsing - improved OCR for charts/diagrams with bounding boxes, confidence scores, and embedded images

items.title: I was a VR advocate for such a long time that this is really personal to me. It's something I got wr...
items.content:
I was a VR advocate for such a long time that this is really personal to me. It's something I got wrong: I thought VR would be a lot more popular than it turned out to be.

Glasses are coming. There were huge crowds around all the glasses booths at CES, but the utility just hasn't shown up yet. Meta focused on games to the detriment of real utility, and I think that cost them.

items.title:
The hard part of building is no longer writing code.

Code is easy.

Nobody wins by writing more cod...
items.content:
The hard part of building is no longer writing code.

Code is easy.

Nobody wins by writing more code or doing it faster. If you want to win, you need better thinking.

There are a ton of startups focusing on using AI to write more code. I think they are missing the plot.

We need a mental shift.

We need tools that help us think faster, make better decisions, and focus on the right problems.

I want you to check out @atoms_dev because they are doing exactly this.

They don't focus on the code, but on helping you build the right structure:

1. It starts by deep-researching marketing insights
2. It turns that into an execution plan
3. It builds both frontend and backend
4. It helps with deployment, SEO, growth, and analytics

More importantly, it specializes in the core components you need to build and sell software online:

‚Ä¢ Authentication flows
‚Ä¢ Stripe payments
‚Ä¢ Infrastructure

Their goal here is not to be another autocomplete tool or a copilot to help you write software.

Their goal is to become a "vibe business team" that helps you build a business from the ground up.

Here is a link for you to check them out: https://t.co/MZjyLiUmc1

Thanks to the team for helping me onboard on the platform and collaborating with me on the post.

items.title:
I've talked a lot about AI glasses at #ces2026, but what about rings?

I bought one of these. 

Why?...
items.content:
I've talked a lot about AI glasses at #ces2026, but what about rings?

I bought one of these. 

Why? 

It is the only device I wear even in the shower. Don‚Äôt worry, I won‚Äôt post any more photos of that. (For those who forgot my wife took a photo of me in the shower wearing Google Glass, which got Google cofounder Larry Page to call me out in front of its developer conference).

Anyway, if I'm in the shower, I just have to push a little button on the ring and talk to it. It takes a note into an app, and when I get out of the shower, I can take that note or transcript and copy it anywhere (or put it into Grok and get a cool thing to happen).

It is basically a little microphone you have everywhere. Useful for AI-first thinkers.

I've talked a lot about AI glasses at #ces2026, but what about rings?

I bought one of these.

Why?

It is the only device I wear even in the shower. Don‚Äôt worry, I won‚Äôt post any more photos of that. (For those who forgot my wife took a photo of me in the shower wearing Google Glass, which got Google cofounder Larry Page to call me out in front of its developer conference).

Anyway, if I'm in the shower, I just have to push a little button on the ring and talk to it. It takes a note into an app, and when I get out of the shower, I can take that note or transcript and copy it anywhere (or put it into Grok and get a cool thing to happen).

It is basically a little microphone you have everywhere. Useful for AI-first thinkers.

items.title: @pbeisel Yeah, I had dinner with Tom Gruber (who ran Siri at Apple at the time) since Siri was launc...
items.content:
@pbeisel Yeah, I had dinner with Tom Gruber (who ran Siri at Apple at the time) since Siri was launched in my house. Back 14 years ago, he told me that Google was learning faster than Apple and that they would have to rebuild Apple's AI from scratch. 

They never did, and that is the lack of leadership you're talking about. It's unfortunate. It is evidence that Apple is a massive company that isn't willing to take risks, and that's going to eventually cost them. I think this particular situation won't cost them too much, but robots are coming, and that is going to be a tough industry for Apple to enter. 

I think the robot industry is going to boot up very quickly:
1. Everyone is going to decide to buy either a Tesla, a Figure, or a Unitree (or whatever comes along in the next 24‚Äì36 months).
2. Apple is going to be very unwilling to get into the robotics world directly because of the lawyers.

It's going to be sad to watch, but that is why we have startups. Big companies go away‚Äîdoes anybody remember AltaVista or Nokia? They all thought they were innovative in their day.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Analysis: Apple's risk aversion and lawyer-driven culture will hurt them in robotics; big companies fail while startups emerge; references AltaVista and Nokia
items.reasoning: Substantive industry analysis about Apple's future in robotics era, draws historical parallels
items.summary_html: Analysis: Apple's risk aversion and lawyer-driven culture will hurt them in robotics; big companies fail while startups emerge; references AltaVista and Nokia

@pbeisel Yeah, I had dinner with Tom Gruber (who ran Siri at Apple at the time) since Siri was launched in my house. Back 14 years ago, he told me that Google was learning faster than Apple and that they would have to rebuild Apple's AI from scratch.

They never did, and that is the lack of leadership you're talking about. It's unfortunate. It is evidence that Apple is a massive company that isn't willing to take risks, and that's going to eventually cost them. I think this particular situation won't cost them too much, but robots are coming, and that is going to be a tough industry for Apple to enter.

I think the robot industry is going to boot up very quickly:

1. Everyone is going to decide to buy either a Tesla, a Figure, or a Unitree (or whatever comes along in the next 24‚Äì36 months).

2. Apple is going to be very unwilling to get into the robotics world directly because of the lawyers.

It's going to be sad to watch, but that is why we have startups. Big companies go away‚Äîdoes anybody remember AltaVista or Nokia? They all thought they were innovative in their day.

items.title: @verbine @shadcn @peteskomoroch Siri was the first consumer app to use AI, and it was launched in my...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Historical context: Siri launched in Scobleizer's house, not LLM-based, Google's AI team was learning faster with fewer privacy constraints - 'post-privacy world' is here
items.reasoning: Valuable first-hand historical perspective on AI development, touches on important privacy implications
items.summary_html: Historical context: Siri launched in Scobleizer's house, not LLM-based, Google's AI team was learning faster with fewer privacy constraints - 'post-privacy world' is here
items.content_html:
@verbine @shadcn @peteskomoroch Siri was the first consumer app to use AI, and it was launched in my house. It wasn't a large language model back then, but it was AI built by three guys out of SRI Labs in Menlo Park.

At that time, the AI was learning faster at Google. Google had a bigger AI team‚Äîand they still do. Furthermore, Google didn't have the same kind of privacy concerns that Apple did. I actually met the head of Google's AI team years ago, and he told me, "If we actually turned on what we could turn on, we would freak you out."

Well, now we are into that freaky world. These things are going to know everything about us, and they already do about me. I am in the post-privacy world. Welcome to the new world.

items.title:
@wholemars The reason this is true is multifold:

1. Smoothness: Tesla's AI is way smoother at stopp...
items.content:
@wholemars The reason this is true is multifold:

1. Smoothness: Tesla's AI is way smoother at stopping, accelerating, going around turns, and staying straight on the freeway. It just is so smooth!
2. Fleet advantage: By the end of the year, you're going to see the advantage of the fleet. It's going to have more information and will be able to navigate around obstacles better. In other words, for things like a closed block or a fire engine closing a road, you're going to see the fleet actually be a major advantage over the others. 

It is so good.

@wholemars The reason this is true is multifold:

1. Smoothness: Tesla's AI is way smoother at stopping, accelerating, going around turns, and staying straight on the freeway. It just is so smooth!

2. Fleet advantage: By the end of the year, you're going to see the advantage of the fleet. It's going to have more information and will be able to navigate around obstacles better. In other words, for things like a closed block or a fire engine closing a road, you're going to see the fleet actually be a major advantage over the others.

It is so good.

items.title: @_Ben_Chalmers The metaverse they developed was really underwhelming and ended up overbalanced by yo...
items.content:
@_Ben_Chalmers The metaverse they developed was really underwhelming and ended up overbalanced by younger users who cluttered it with low-quality content. It's interesting that Meta hasn't been able to put it all together. 

This makes sense because all the executives grew up in a 2D world; they just couldn't get to the point where they truly loved or nurtured the VR world. I saw them make so many mistakes over the years. Maybe I'll do a longer post about it later, but probably not‚ÄîI've said enough. It's just a depressing end.

items.title:
And the software stack itself is about to face a reckoning.

20th century architectures cannot keep ...
items.content:
And the software stack itself is about to face a reckoning.

20th century architectures cannot keep up with agentic AI.

They require heart surgery every time a policy, org structure, or product changes.

Winning companies will adopt platforms that separate:

‚Üí Data
‚Üí Business logic
‚Üí Workflows

This creates systems that evolve continuously instead of breaking every quarter.

The vendor relationship shifts from procurement to true partnership.

items.title:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X t...
items.content:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X then Y.

AI is probabilistic and pattern unlocking.

This requires leaders to:

‚Üí Reimagine every process, not digitize the old one.
‚Üí Empower every employee with AI capability.
‚Üí Redesign workflows that adapt dynamically to business outcomes instead of rigid rules.

This is a fundamentally different operating model.

items.title:
Most companies claim they are becoming AI first.

Almost none understand what that actually requires...
items.content:
Most companies claim they are becoming AI first.

Almost none understand what that actually requires.

The surprising truth: AI does not transform your business by automating existing workflows. It transforms it by replacing deterministic workflows entirely.

I explore this with @hala_zeine, Chief Strategy Officer at @ServiceNow.

#ServiceNowPartner
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Introduces interview with ServiceNow CSO about AI replacing deterministic workflows entirely rather than just automating them
items.reasoning: Sponsored but substantive framing of AI transformation, challenges conventional automation narrative
items.summary_html: Introduces interview with ServiceNow CSO about AI replacing deterministic workflows entirely rather than just automating them
items.content_html:
Most companies claim they are becoming AI first.

Almost none understand what that actually requires.

The surprising truth: AI does not transform your business by automating existing workflows. It transforms it by replacing deterministic workflows entirely.

I explore this with @hala_zeine, Chief Strategy Officer at @ServiceNow.

#ServiceNowPartner

items.title:
The biggest barrier isn't technology. It is legacy complexity.

Take aviation as an example.

A majo...
items.content:
The biggest barrier isn't technology. It is legacy complexity.

Take aviation as an example.

A major airline operates over 1,000 aircraft supported by 80 separate homegrown apps.

IFS CEO Mark Moffat warns that AI can't fix that complexity alone.

You have to use simulation at scale to pressure-test workflows millions of times before they touch a real turbine.

items.title:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People ...
items.content:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People love the idea of change. They just prefer it to happen to someone else.

What works:

‚Üí Leaders who communicate the vision repeatedly.
‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.
‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Discusses fear as biggest blocker to AI adoption, emphasizes leadership communication and experimentation culture
items.reasoning: Practical organizational insight on AI transformation challenges, quotes industry expert
items.summary_html: Discusses fear as biggest blocker to AI adoption, emphasizes leadership communication and experimentation culture
items.content_html:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

What works:

‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.

‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.

items.content:
@AutoMindMa65102 The reality is we're all addicted to our mobile phones. Can anything come along to disrupt that? 

We'll find out in the next couple of years if anyone gives up their phone to work mostly in glasses. I think that's even further away, though‚Äîprobably five to seven years. 

Five to seven years from now, we're going to see:
1. Brain-computer interfaces
2. Robots

These developments will likely distract us even further.

items.title: @compliantvc @zhihuipikachu I don't believe that's true because they're not actually recording you. ...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Argues transcription vs recording distinction in AI glasses privacy debate, claims rules on headphones are unenforceable
items.reasoning: Substantive perspective on AI wearables privacy debate, raises legal/practical arguments
items.summary_html: Argues transcription vs recording distinction in AI glasses privacy debate, claims rules on headphones are unenforceable
items.content_html:
@compliantvc @zhihuipikachu I don't believe that's true because they're not actually recording you. See, if you made it about recording, you might be right, but they don't record; they transcribe. That is very different.

Legally, it doesn't matter. Any rules on headphones are not enforceable because you don't know what my headphones are doing, just like I don't know what the phone in your pocket can do. By the way, the phone in your pocket can hear everything discussed at dinner (I've already tried that).

You are going to lose this argument.

items.title: @jsof2010 @shadcn @peteskomoroch Interesting! I talked to an entrepreneur yesterday who said his who...
items.content:
@jsof2010 @shadcn @peteskomoroch Interesting! I talked to an entrepreneur yesterday who said his whole team uses Gemini and they love it. I asked him, "Doesn't it hallucinate or give you bad answers?" and he said it hasn't in their experience.

It must be something about how they're prompting it or the kind of workloads they're asking for that's different from yours. It would be interesting to get a group of people together‚Äîboth those who are pro and con all these systems‚Äîto do a little comparison. That way, we can get a better handle on what each model does well and what it doesn't do well.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Discussion about entrepreneur whose team loves Gemini without hallucination issues, suggesting prompting/workload differences matter
items.reasoning: Useful real-world feedback on Gemini performance, highlights importance of use-case-specific evaluation
items.summary_html: Discussion about entrepreneur whose team loves Gemini without hallucination issues, suggesting prompting/workload differences matter
items.content_html:
@jsof2010 @shadcn @peteskomoroch Interesting! I talked to an entrepreneur yesterday who said his whole team uses Gemini and they love it. I asked him, "Doesn't it hallucinate or give you bad answers?" and he said it hasn't in their experience.

It must be something about how they're prompting it or the kind of workloads they're asking for that's different from yours. It would be interesting to get a group of people together‚Äîboth those who are pro and con all these systems‚Äîto do a little comparison. That way, we can get a better handle on what each model does well and what it doesn't do well.

@IlirAliu_ I'm really impressed by what I see. Are they ahead of 1X or Sunday Robotics? I don't know, but that's not the point.

The real point is: who can get this into manufacturing and get it into homes or businesses? It's too early to call that one.

That said, this is very impressive.

items.title: @Rufus87078959 The gaming ecosystem is fairly robust on VR headsets. However, my son is 16 and in th...
items.content:
@Rufus87078959 The gaming ecosystem is fairly robust on VR headsets. However, my son is 16 and in the prime age for VR, but none of his friends have it, so he doesn't feel any need to use it.

He's always on Discord, playing Minecraft, Roblox, or a bunch of different games on his 2D screen. That is telling: the teenage set just doesn't find a need for VR.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Observation that VR gaming hasn't captured teenagers - Scobleizer's 16yo son and friends don't use VR, preferring Discord and 2D games

items.title:
This note is just for the Tesla fans, or anybody in an autonomous car like a Waymo. 

I find I'm jus...
items.content:
This note is just for the Tesla fans, or anybody in an autonomous car like a Waymo. 

I find I'm just starting to really love @typelessdotcom . I tried its competitor, @WisprFlow , but Typeless has a better user interface for me. At least on my iPhone.

It is just so freaking good! I'm on the freeway right now talking to you, and I just push a button, start talking, push it again, and it puts the post up. 

It's freaking amazing how fast I can talk compared to typing on a little phone screen. I can even sort of pay attention to the road (which I'm still supposed to be doing, because we're still in unsupervised Tesla mode), but let's be honest: it's driving so well I don't look at the road very much anymore. 

Anyways, have a great day!
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer loves Typeless voice typing while in Tesla on autopilot, demonstrates voice-to-post workflow
items.reasoning: Practical demonstration of AI tool convergence: autonomous driving + voice AI for productivity
items.summary_html: Scobleizer loves Typeless voice typing while in Tesla on autopilot, demonstrates voice-to-post workflow
items.content_html:
This note is just for the Tesla fans, or anybody in an autonomous car like a Waymo.

I find I'm just starting to really love @typelessdotcom . I tried its competitor, @WisprFlow , but Typeless has a better user interface for me. At least on my iPhone.

It is just so freaking good! I'm on the freeway right now talking to you, and I just push a button, start talking, push it again, and it puts the post up.

It's freaking amazing how fast I can talk compared to typing on a little phone screen. I can even sort of pay attention to the road (which I'm still supposed to be doing, because we're still in unsupervised Tesla mode), but let's be honest: it's driving so well I don't look at the road very much anymore.

Anyways, have a great day!

items.title: @Duhmeee @4SigmaSmarter @esrtweet @geerlingguy @SpaceX @Starlink All you need for positioning is fou...
items.content: @Duhmeee @4SigmaSmarter @esrtweet @geerlingguy @SpaceX @Starlink All you need for positioning is four visible sats. You need somewhat more sats in the constellation in LEO vs MEO to guarantee four continuously visible, but that is dozens, not thousands. Am I missing something? They would need new receivers, so it isn‚Äôt surprising they haven‚Äôt ‚Äúalready been running it as GPS‚Äù, but new applications could be made more robust with the larger constellation.

items.content:
@javilopen Or is it just that the service gets freaking popular because everybody talks about it on X? So everybody adopts it, therefore there's a huge amount of new demand and everything gets slow.

I don't know, maybe there's a bigger conspiracy theory, but I think it's just like a new restaurant that gets a good review. It then gets really busy, and you have to wait in line to get in!

It's much less risky to train at lower weights but higher reps th...
items.content:
This is why I stopped ego lifting

It's much less risky to train at lower weights but higher reps than to ego lift to your one max rep (1RM)

And you get the same results

I've never had an injury and I like to keep it that way

items.title: The opening of Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week 2026 by HE Dr Sultan Al Jaber framed the energy transfo...
items.content:
The opening of Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week 2026 by HE Dr Sultan Al Jaber framed the energy transformation as a systems challenge that requires coherence across sectors, echoing the idea that ‚Äúthe corridor to the future runs through the UAE.‚Äù

Partnership with @ADSWagenda #ADSW

The delivery side matters: people, infrastructure, and long-term execution determine whether ambition becomes reality. Sustainability was presented as the result of alignment across energy, industry, finance, policy, and human development.

This systems-oriented approach has guided Masdar since its early foundations, long before renewables were proven at global scale. Today, integrated green development is framed as a driver of prosperity, resilience, and opportunity.

ADSW 2026 reflects a moment of maturity for the global sustainability agenda, where the focus is shifting toward delivery, infrastructure, and the ability to translate long-term vision into platforms that support progress over time.

Learn more on the official website > https://t.co/Ch0X5ygGpi

items.title: Sitting in the @VW service center in Quebec City. I've been their client for many years, and every t...
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov complains about VW service center's database system failing to recognize him, notes even 'dumb machines' can write code and change databases now
items.reasoning: Tangential AI reference criticizing outdated enterprise systems. Commentary on gap between AI capabilities and enterprise adoption.
items.summary_html: Burkov complains about VW service center's database system failing to recognize him, notes even 'dumb machines' can write code and change databases now
items.content_html:
Sitting in the @VW service center in Quebec City. I've been their client for many years, and every time I want to make an appointment online, their system doesn't recognize my phone number, so I have to first type in all parameters online and then repeat them in person.

I asked the associates in the center to fix this; they said it's impossible. Literally: "Sorry, it's impossible to add you in the system if it doesn't recognize you."

@VW, you are probably not aware, but for a couple of years now, even the dumb machines can write code and change databases. Will you eventually learn to do that?

items.title: Here's my conversation with Paul Rosolie, his 3rd time on the podcast, about his intense recent expe...
items.content:
Here's my conversation with Paul Rosolie, his 3rd time on the podcast, about his intense recent experience in the Amazon Jungle of a full-on encounter with the warriors of an uncontacted tribe. We show never-before-seen footage of this encounter. It's one of the most incredible things I've ever seen, and the whole story is fascinating.

Long-form video upload on X doesn't seem to be working at the moment, so only YouTube, Spotify, RSS for now:

YouTube: https://t.co/aw9cCWn3HH

Spotify: https://t.co/ZMtg5QCvFo

Podcast: https://t.co/7AZXIxZ0sh

Timestamps:
0:00 - Episode highlight
1:08 - Introduction
3:59 - Uncontacted tribes in the Amazon Jungle
11:45 - Intense recent encounter
34:51 - Never-before-seen footage of tribe warriors
48:07 - The mysteries of the jungle
1:02:42 - Tribe's diet: Monkeys, turtles, and turtle eggs
1:12:18 - Jane Goodall
1:18:30 - Advice for young people
1:27:44 - Cartel, Narco-traffickers & assassination attempts
1:49:44 - Climbing the giant tree
2:00:42 - Giant anaconda
2:18:00 - Rescuing a spider monkey
2:24:04 - Dangerous animal encounters
2:34:12 - Writing, journaling, and great writer inspirations

items.title: @STWxAi @DavidMoss @typelessdotcom @WisprFlow That's another reason I like using miles: I like to se...
items.content:
@STWxAi @DavidMoss @typelessdotcom @WisprFlow That's another reason I like using miles: I like to see how inaccurate the reading is. I know it's probably about 30% inaccurate; for example, when it says San Francisco is 50 miles away, it generally uses about 80 miles worth of power.

Generally, I can get from San Jose to San Francisco and back, and I usually have somewhere between 5% and 15% left when I get home. If I'm not going to make it home‚Äîlet's say I went to Marin or somewhere like that‚Äîthen it will have me stop and get a quick supercharge on the way back.

items.title: @jonnyjkane Well, it's sort of true. I've never met Scott‚Äîwe've never even talked that I remember‚Äîbu...
items.content:
@jonnyjkane Well, it's sort of true. I've never met Scott‚Äîwe've never even talked that I remember‚Äîbut he followed me and I followed him. That was our relationship. Now I don't have a follower that I had yesterday because he died, and it's a bummer.

Anyways, he brought a lot of joy into my life. Sometimes he forced me to think differently, and I appreciate that too.

items.content: @OT_ecoeco Why are you centering everyone in the US? Just because someone in the US is cheering something, that is what makes it legitimate or not? Why wouldn't I listen to the ordinary Iranians whose people are getting massacred? Just because people I dislike are cheering them on, I should completely discount people whose government is massacring them and are out on the street? I should only think about what my enemy of my enemy is doing and calculate who I should support vs not solely based on what the US government says? Like the voices of any other people don't count? Shame.

items.title: @garsay10 @negar_rz @AJENews If there was a protest in Eritrea, that's exactly how our so-called lef...
items.content: @garsay10 @negar_rz @AJENews If there was a protest in Eritrea, that's exactly how our so-called leftists in the US would also describe it. They would describe all our people dying on the streets as Mossad agents and all of our massacred people lies. Talk to ordinary Iranians, not government's kids or officials, and you'll see that the death toll is actually underreported by the west. People are scared, being massacred under a complete blackout and they're talking about how they can't believe that the left in the west is negating what they're trying to raise awareness. We can fight their revolution being hijacked but to make them also fight to bring their narrative into light would make us cruel, like the people who do that to us.

items.title: @DavidMoss @typelessdotcom @WisprFlow I like miles because I know how many miles it is to San Franci...
items.content:
@DavidMoss @typelessdotcom @WisprFlow I like miles because I know how many miles it is to San Francisco, which is where I'm headed right now, and I know how many miles it is to get home. 

I prefer looking at miles; percentages are a little wacky for me. But everybody has their own preferences, and that's why the setting is there in the settings.

items.title:
Turkey grabbed a part of Cyprus, and both countries are happily in NATO.

The U.S. will grab Greenla...
items.content:
Turkey grabbed a part of Cyprus, and both countries are happily in NATO.

The U.S. will grab Greenland, and the Danes will remain happy too. They will admit they were always worried about the island's safety, but now, thanks to our U.S. allies controlling the island, this piece of NATO territory is secure as never before.

It's only when Russia does something it's a blatant violation of international law. When it's our son of a bitch, that's different and not that simple.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov discusses Turkey/Cyprus, US/Greenland geopolitics and selective application of international law
items.reasoning: Political commentary unrelated to AI/ML.
items.summary_html: Burkov discusses Turkey/Cyprus, US/Greenland geopolitics and selective application of international law
items.content_html:
Turkey grabbed a part of Cyprus, and both countries are happily in NATO.

The U.S. will grab Greenland, and the Danes will remain happy too. They will admit they were always worried about the island's safety, but now, thanks to our U.S. allies controlling the island, this piece of NATO territory is secure as never before.

It's only when Russia does something it's a blatant violation of international law. When it's our son of a bitch, that's different and not that simple.
